title: A death
content:
I heard today from folks and sister that some young woman (a year younger than me, I guess) had died in an accident, a car had crashed in her bicycle. I couldn't connect the name with any face or anything after I heard it, but my sister thought she had heard the name and thought the girl had been in the same high school where she is now -- and where I had been before. And true enough, I decided to check my high school year book and look at the persons one year younger, and there was the name and face. It was strange seeing that face there, even if I certainly didn't know her, never said a word or anything.

I don't know much about the actual accident, but it must've been horrible for her to see a car approaching and know that there's nothing she can do anymore. (In case she saw it. But it feels somehow more horrible if she didn't, I guess.) She had been in university for two days (since it just started), seemingly a bright girl with hopes and dreams for the future, all gone now.

You guys probably get a good laugh about my sentimentality; I know (duh) millions of people (or perhaps a bit less) die every day, but it doesn't affect me most of the time, but for some reason this did.

Anyways, we're too fragile... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-no.gif[/img] 3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: A life
content:
I've known a couple of people who have died in car accidents. In both instances it seemed no different to before, since they were both people with whom I'd not associated for some time. It was just as though they were among the innumerable people I've known but who have moved on out of my life and I never expect to see again.

The funerals made it real to me, and made me appreciate just what each person had meant in my life, and indeed the lives of the vast circle of people who attended.

It's interesting that these things happen so frequently to those who we would consider to have 'bright futures'. Smart, happy, undeniably present. Gives me reason to think they've just outgrown their lives here and have more important things to attend to, like those who move on from the PCKF.

I had an interesting dream many years ago (and before the aforementioned deaths) in which a close friend, known as Donny, had died by some undisclosed means. I was attending a party with some friends, and thought it strange that it didn't bother me. I kind of shrugged and thought, "Hmm, Donny's dead... that's weird."

There's something that makes this particularly intriguing. Around the time KeenRush posted this, I was on my holiday to Queensland with Donny and his girlfriend, Caz. Caz had a dream just like mine, where Donny had died and she wasn't upset at all, just thought about how strange it was.

Now it really would be weird.

Now that I think about it, my beliefs work fairly well with that theme. I've experienced enough supernatural weirdness and uncanny coincidences to form a good basis for a belief that when people die it is just like if they'd simply moved out of your life like so many others do. As if this existence is a toy and they're done playing with it for now.
